subject: Programming By Contract
msgSnippet: According to the release notes with v3.1 of JUnit (the version we re using) the junit.framework.Assert class was created specifically so you can do Programming
messageBody:
According to the release notes with v3.1 of JUnit (the version we're
using) the junit.framework.Assert class was created specifically so
you can do Programming By Contract i.e. make calls like

Assert.assertNotNull(myObject)

directly in your code and have it throw an AssertionFailedException.
This is good news, but the question is: does anyone know why
AssertionFailedException is an Error and not a RuntimeException -
according to Sun's guidelines on exception handling you should not be
trying to catch and handle Errors, but I do want to, in order to be
able to display a 'pretty' error message in my production system.

Any thoughts?

Tony Heap
